question: An increase in the pCO2 level of the blood characterizes respiratory alkalosis.

Na+-K+ ATPase is involved in the active transport of Na+ in the kidneys.

Sickle Cell Anemia is characterized by a point mutation in both genes coding for the alpha chain of hemoglobin resulting in polymer formation upon deoxygenation.

More than half of the adult population worldwide suffers from lactose intolerance due to lactase deficiency.
Glycolysis results in the production of pyruvate.
The reaction catalyzed by phosphoglycerate kinase is physiologically reversible.
In tissues with a high oxidative capacity such as cardiac muscle, pyruvate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to produce lactate.

Glucagon stimulates gluconeogenesis through at least three distinct biochemical pathways.
Gluconeogenesis generates new glucose molecules exclusively through carbohydrate sources.
In muscle, calcium activates glycogen phosphorylase without requiring its prior activation through phosphorylation mechanisms.
Galactose 1-phosphate needs to be converted to UDP-galactose before it can enter the glycolytic pathway or participate in biosynthetic reactions.

Hypochlorous acid is the primary agent involved in the destruction of ingested microbes during oxidative burst.
Prolactin increases the expression of β-galactosidase during milk production in mammals.
A person with normally functioning kidneys will start excreting glucose in their urine once their blood glucose level exceeds the renal threshold of approximately 180 mg/dl.

Chondroitin 4- and 6-sulfates are types of glycoproteins.
Fatty acyl-CoA synthetase participates in the process of assembling triacylglycerols during their synthesis inside intestinal mucosal cells.

Lingual lipase acts on triglycerides with long-chain fatty acids in the mouth and stomach.
Oxidation of one molecule of palmitoyl-CoA yields more than 130 ATP molecules after accounting for activation costs.
Acetyl CoA carries two-carbon units from the mitochondrial matrix to the cytosol.

Ammonia is transported in the bloodstream mainly bound to urea.

Type 1 diabetes mellitus always presents with ketoacidosis, while type 2 never does.
